critique: This document is a short executive order from 1933. It pertains to the appointment of Thomas H. Allen as a special investigator in the Immigration Service of the Department of Labor, exempting him from civil service rules. The justification is his 'highly meritorious service under most trying and difficult circumstances.' Given the historical context (early 1930s), immigration policies were likely more restrictive than today. The order itself seems to expand executive power by bypassing standard hiring procedures. There's not enough information to assess its impact on federalism, national security vs. civil liberties, economic regulation, or social inclusion. The ideological tilt is hard to gauge without more context, but the action of bypassing civil service rules might lean slightly conservative (favoring efficiency/results over process).
